report_title: Industry Research: Food Processor & Blender Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2023 currency. Food processor and blender manufacturers make electric- and motor-driven appliances used in food preparation. The strong economy in the years before the COVID-19 pandemic caused per capita disposable income to rise, enabling consumers to spend more on the industry's products, which raised revenue. Social distancing and mask-wearing rules made industrial production more difficult when the pandemic hit. The supply of many of the industry's key inputs fell, constraining revenue for manufacturers. Supply chain disruptions ensued during the COVID-19 pandemic's recovery, causing plastic prices to soar. Since plastic is a primary input for food processors and blenders, high plastic prices have caused revenue to skyrocket recently because manufacturers have been able to pass on high costs to their buyers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue growth aided by rising incomes before pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The strong economy before the COVID-19 pandemic caused per capita disposable income to rise, enabling consumers to spend more on the industry's products like blenders and food processors, boosting revenue growth.
Social distancing and mask rules during the pandemic made industrial production more difficult, reducing the supply of key inputs and constraining revenue growth for manufacturers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Supply chain disruptions caused soaring plastic prices
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Plastic manufacturers scaled down production during the pandemic. They couldn't raise supply fast enough during the recovery, causing plastic prices to skyrocket. Since plastic is a major input, manufacturers passed on higher costs, boosting revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic recovery to encourage revenue growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Steady GDP growth will raise incomes, encouraging purchases of blenders and food processors. The strong economy will also enable R&D investment to improve products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Falling plastic prices to dampen revenue growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As plastic supply increases to match demand, eliminating disruptions, plastic price growth will fall. Since manufacturers benefit from passing on high input costs, lower plastic prices will reduce revenue growth.
To reduce costs, big manufacturers will likely shift more production of basic products to developing countries with lower wages, threatening domestic industry revenue.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures electric- and motor-driven appliances used in food preparation. More specifically, companies manufacture blenders, food processors, stand mixers, slicers, whippers, tenderizers, molders and several other appliances used in slicing, chopping, grinding, shredding, pureeing, crushing and mixing food items.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Per capita disposable income
threats: Private investment in industrial equipment and machinery

key_trends: Rising incomes made it easier for households to afford blenders, slicers, choppers and other types of food processors
Slow industrial production reduced the supply of many vital inputs for food processors and blenders
Plastic manufacturers scaled down their production during the pandemic to match declining demand
The strong economy will give big manufacturers the money to conduct more research and development
As time passes, plastic manufacturers will increase their supply to match demand for their materials
Foreigners will become more attracted to food processors and blenders made in the United States, so exports will rise
Since plastic is a primary input for food processors and blenders, high plastic prices have caused revenue to skyrocket

market_segmentation.segment_description: Wholesalers and distributors that supply food processors and blenders to department stores, restaurants, hotels and other establishments comprise more than half of revenue since wholesalers efficiently transfer goods between two points.
Warehouse clubs and Supercenters such as Walmart and Costco sell food processors and blenders because these stores offer a wide range of products that appeal to many customers.

products_and_services.product_description: Blenders, slicers, choppers, grinders, cutters, dicers and other machines are common staples in many households, they comprise nearly half of revenue.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Food Processors including Mixers and Parts and Attachments
products_and_services.product_description: Food processors are used for whipping, chopping, shredding and mixing food. These processors are customizable, so consumers often purchase parts for them (e.g., blades) separately.
Tenderizers are hand-powered tools used to make meat more suitable for eating. Other products in this segment include electric mini-choppers, ice crushers and baby food makers.

tier_1_suppliers: Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
Plastic & Resin Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Laminated Plastics Manufacturing in the US
Electrical Equipment Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US
TV & Appliance Wholesaling in the US
Consumer Electronics Stores in the US
Accommodation and Food Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Influenced by consumer confidence and disposable income levels. When these factors increase, consumers are more willing to purchase non-essential goods like food processors and blenders.
Demand is highly influenced by changing consumer preferences, irrespective of economic conditions. Blenders and food processors are purchased for convenience and quick food preparation.
Demand is heavily dependent on exchange rates, both domestically and abroad. Exchange rates influence relative prices of domestic vs foreign products.
As the number of grocery stores, fish markets, and meat markets increase, they are more inclined to make capital expenditures on food service equipment, driving industry growth.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Food processor and blender manufacturers face threats from producers abroad. As per capita GDP in developing countries has risen, workers in these nations have moved past subsistence, so manufacturing has been popping up. Since wages are lower in these nations relative to the United States, companies have started to offshore their production to developing countries to reduce costs.

The COVID-19 pandemic made it difficult to transport materials. When the pandemic hit, the United States government severely restricted international trade and migration to stop the spread of the virus. It became incredibly hard for food processors and blenders to transport goods out of the United States because of these rules, so exports plunged in 2020.

The Trump administration imposed tariffs on China to encourage domestic production. These actions caused China to raise its tariffs, initiating a trade war. The trade war has hurt import and export markets between the world's two largest economies, so exports from China have declined.

The USMCA was signed in 2019 and was made effective in 2020. The law reduced tariffs between the United States, Mexico and Canada for many goods, strengthening trade ties between the three North American countries. These provisions caused Canada and Mexico's share of food processor and blender exports to increase.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the highest population of any region because it contains big states such as Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and Tennessee. Since the Southeast has the most people, demand for food is high, raising spending on food processors and blenders and causing lots of manufacturers to locate in the region. Ready access to low-wage and non-union labor in the region has also encouraged manufacturers to set up shop there.

The Great Lakes region is the second-largest in terms of establishments, where Illinois, Michigan and Ohio contain a significant number of food processor and blender manufacturers. The Great Lakes region is a hotbed for manufacturing across industries, including iron and steel, aluminum, electrical equipment and plastic and resin makers.

The Southwest, particularly Texas, is heavily involved in crude oil extraction and processing. Oil and gas are often necessary for the production of food processors and blenders, so many manufacturers locate in the region to save money on energy costs.

regulations_points.regulation_description: This law requires that companies comply with limits on the emission of pollutants. These rules apply to food processor and blender manufacturers because the materials required to build the industry's products often pollute the air. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) applies allowances for the level of sulfur, nitrogen oxides, ozone and other pollutants companies can release into the atmosphere.

Manufacturers produce waste when they make food processors and blenders, so they could pollute nearby streams and lakes to eliminate this waste. This act ensures that the industry doesn't pollute bodies of water.

Manufacturers are governed by laws and regulations relating to workplace safety and worker health. OSHA covers several topics regarding time off, hours and workers' compensation. These also include staff training on working with hazardous chemicals. Companies are also held accountable to various state OSHAs, which may vary from their federal counterpart.

Food processor and blender manufacturers must comply with product safety rules so customers aren't harmed by purchasing their materials. The government also requires companies to label their products, as it ensures that customers have an accurate understanding of what they're purchasing.

To ensure that COVID-19 didn't spread, governments forced food processor and blender manufacturers to make their employees socially distance and wear masks. Some establishments also required their employees to receive the COVID-19 vaccine when it became available.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, increasing barriers to entry.
The industry has a high and steady level of globalization, increasing barriers.
The industry has a low capital intensity level, decreasing barriers to entry.
The industry has a low level of market concentration, decreasing barriers.
No specialized license required, but regulations must be followed.
High start-up costs for machinery, equipment, labor, rent and utilities.
Branding is important to establish reputation and supply relationships.
The industry is labor-intensive, increasing labor costs as a barrier.

basis_points.basis_description: Price and quality are significant factors influencing purchasing decisions.
Players compete on patented technologies from research and development.
Relationships with dealers/distributors and branding offer advantages.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Import penetration, especially from China, has hindered concentration.
High start-up costs prevent some individuals from entering the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Plastic prices have a big influence on revenue growth
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Since food processor and blender manufacturers can pass on high input prices to their buyers, revenue soars when the price of plastic materials and resin increases. Manufacturers lose this ability when plastic prices decline, so revenue falls.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Higher incomes help consumers purchase the industry's products
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: When per capita disposable income rises, more consumers can purchase food processors and blenders, raising revenue. As incomes decline, it's harder for Americans to buy these products, inhibiting revenue growth.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The strength of imports is affected by many factors
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Since imports are a significant substitute for domestic food processor and blender manufacturers, their strength significantly impacts the industry's performance. The performance of imports is dependent on exchange rates, inflation, the rate of interest, per capita disposable incomes and relations between other countries.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Food Processor and Blender Manufacturing industry has a low level of capital intensity, with the average company spending $0.07 on capital for every $1.00 spent on labor. The industry's relatively high labor intensity reflects the importance of workers in making food processors and blenders.

Due to the relative complexity of products, some capital expenditures are necessary for food processor and blender manufacturers. Though this industry consists primarily of small- to medium-size companies, prominent players generate a significant share of revenue. These companies also invest more in capital, raising the industry's average capital intensity.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Plastic prices have a big influence on revenue growth
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since food processor and blender manufacturers can pass on high input prices to their buyers, revenue soars when the price of plastic materials and resin increases. Manufacturers lose this ability when plastic prices decline, so revenue falls. The price of plastic materials and resin declined during the COVID-19 pandemic but surged during the recovery amid supply chain disruptions, so shifting plastic prices enhanced revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Higher incomes help consumers purchase the industry's products
volatility_points.volatility_description: When per capita disposable income rises, more consumers can purchase food processors and blenders, raising revenue. As incomes decline, it's harder for Americans to buy these products, inhibiting revenue growth. Government aid caused per capita disposable income to surge during the COVID-19 pandemic, while the termination of these subsidies caused incomes to decline. These big fluctuations contributed to revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The strength of imports is affected by many factors
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since imports are a significant substitute for domestic food processor and blender manufacturers, their strength significantly impacts the industry's performance. The performance of imports is dependent on exchange rates, inflation, the rate of interest, per capita disposable incomes and relations between other countries.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Companies use standard technologies to streamline production
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Technologies used by companies in the Food Processor and Blender Manufacturing industry vary by product segment, though more prominent manufacturers use standard technologies to streamline production and reduce costs. For instance, most large manufacturers use computer-controlled machinery and other automated handling and assembly technology to perform repetitive tasks.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: New materials and components facilitate product modifications
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The types of materials used as inputs in the manufacturing process are also changing, with lighter and more durable materials used for product modifications. In addition, compact electronic components have facilitated the miniaturization of many appliances and fostered sophisticated functions on otherwise mature products, such as electronic controls on blenders.

Furthermore, efficient rechargeable batteries have led to the developing of a wide range of battery-powered appliances. These appeal to individuals on the go, as they tend to double as convenient drinking containers.
Large players have also established e-commerce systems for retailers, which enable buyers to obtain product information and download it in-store, order products and access stock data.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Rising import penetration has limited revenue growth for both small and large companies in this industry.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Since the products manufactured in the industry are technologically less advanced, rising import penetration from China and Mexico has decimated revenue growth.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices recently?
FAQs.answer: The fall in the price of plastics and resins has decreased purchases for companies in the industry.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation during the current period?
FAQs.answer: Wages still account for a high share of revenue in this industry.

FAQs.question: Do you use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of your company's manufacturing, sales, inventory and distribution channels?
FAQs.answer: Technology has remained relatively stagnant during the current period.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulation is steady in the industry with no import tariffs on most products manufactured.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Energy-efficient standards are exceeded by large manufacturers.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit has held steady during the current period.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit recently?
FAQs.answer: While input costs have increased, purchases have held steady because manufacturers have been able to pass on high prices to their buyers.

FAQs.question: How has the current amount of automation in your company affected your labor costs? How can you incorporate more automation?
FAQs.answer: Automation can help to substantially reduce labor costs, which are high for domestic manufacturers in comparison to manufacturers located in many countries abroad.

FAQs.question: Do you regularly engage in market research? What has the market research you've conducted shown you about the needs of your consumers and retailers?
FAQs.answer: Good market research helps manufacturers understand the needs of consumers and retailers, as well as anticipate and respond to the actions of competitors.

FAQs.question: How have you established a strong brand name? Do you offer loyal customers special deals or discounts?
FAQs.answer: The establishment of a well-known brand name can have a significant impact in increasing sales.

FAQs.question: What effects has the price of plastic materials and resin had on your company thus far? How can you adapt when the price increases?
FAQs.answer: Growth in the price of these materials tends to raise purchases. If these costs cannot be fully passed on to downstream customers, profit will fall.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index? How has the falling dollar affected demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: Since imports satisfy a large and growing share of domestic demand for blenders and because exports represent a crucial source of revenue, a rising TWI tends to have a strong negative impact on the industry.

FAQs.question: How have changes in disposable income influenced demand for your products? How do you plan to take advantage of rising disposable income?
FAQs.answer: Since food processors and blenders are discretionary purchases, a rise in per capita disposable income increases the propensity for customers to purchase more expensive, higher-quality products.
